title: Introducci√≥n al Procesamiento de datos con R
text:
Presentaci√≥n
El taller tiene como principal objetivo introducir a los y las participantes en el mundo de R y la programaci√≥n para producir informaci√≥n estad√≠stica descriptiva. La idea es centrarse en c√≥mo encarar un proyecto que involucre meter manos en los datos, desde c√≥mo nombrar las carpetas o archivos, importarlos para acceder a la informaci√≥n, limpiar y procesarla hasta como visualizar, analizar y comunicar los hallazgos.

title: Introducci√≥n al Procesamiento de datos con R
text:
¬øPara qui√©n?
Para toda aquella persona que quiera / necesite trabajar con datos de una forma m√°s sistem√°tica, ordenada y productiva. No se requiere conocimientos previos de ning√∫n lenguaje de programaci√≥n en particular, aunque siempre es de ayuda haberse cruzado al menos con una sintaxis o haber utilizado alguna f√≥rmula en Excel.

title: Introducci√≥n al Procesamiento de datos con R
text:
¬øC√≥mo?
La programaci√≥n no es un tema de mentes brillantes, sino m√°s bien de aquellas perseverantes. Con este lema bajo el brazo es que se pens√≥ el curso, el cual se focaliza en lo pr√°ctico. No s√≥lo se van a ofrecer ejercicios para resolver c√≥digo entre clase y clase sino que vamos a escribir R durante el encuentro sincr√≥nico, compartiendo pantallas y dudas en vivo!

title: Introducci√≥n al Procesamiento de datos con R
text:
¬øQu√© te llevas?

üë•Ô∏è Acceso irrestrico al foro y sus canales de debate Estaci√≥n R, donde vas a poder encontrarte con colegas de otras disciplinas o √°reas que est√°n transitando su recorrido en R (incicial o avanzado). All√≠ podr√°s compartir, consultar (o tambi√©n responder) cosillas de R y m√°s!
üìë Todos los scripts (el c√≥digo) de lo que se ve durante la clase, junto a las diapositivas.
üéûÔ∏è Acceso a las clases grabadas durante 3 meses, para que puedas seguir repasando y practicando lo visto durante la cursada
üìì ‚ÄòNotas de clase‚Äô, con todo el c√≥digo que se fue escribiendo en vivo durante la clase.
üß∞ Una bater√≠a de recursos (bibliograf√≠a, referentes del mundo R, espacios de difusi√≥n, webs con herramientas, y hasta incluso otros cursos) para explotar al m√°ximo el recorrido inicial y tambi√©n post cursada.

title: Programa
text:
M√≥dulo I: Presentaci√≥n del lenguaje R.

R base.
Data frames (bases de datos)
Paquetes
Proyectos de trabajo con RStudio



M√≥dulo II: Procesamiento de datos con el paquete Tidyverse:

Importaci√≥n de datos (de Excel, SPSS, Stata, archivos de texto, etc.)
Limpieza: Seleccionar variables, filtrar casos, recodificar, renombrar, ordenar y agrupar informaci√≥n.
Tratamiento de valores faltantes (missing values/ NA¬¥s)
Construir medidas de resumen de la informaci√≥n



M√≥dulo III: Visualizaci√≥n de la informaci√≥n

Paquete ggplot2:
Gr√°ficos de l√≠nea, barras, Boxplots
Chapa y pintura: Leyendas, ejes, t√≠tulos, notas, colores, escala



M√≥dulo IV: Introducci√≥n al armado de informes/reportes con RMarkdown

Aspectos b√°sicos de html
Recopilaci√≥n y procesamiento de datos de la web











No matching items

title: Puesta a punto
text:
Este taller est√° pensado para ser esencialmente pr√°ctico. La idea es exponer una presentaci√≥n por m√≥dulo, en donde cada 3 o 4 conceptos se le dedicar√° un tiempo para poder ejercitar lo visto, previo a continuar con el siguiente contenido.
Se recomienda seguir las presentaciones durante la exposici√≥n ya que de ellas se extraer√° el c√≥digo, haciendo m√°s √°gil la cursada.

title: Puesta a punto
text:
Este taller est√° pensado para ser esencialmente pr√°ctico. La idea es exponer una presentaci√≥n por m√≥dulo, en donde cada 3 o 4 conceptos se le dedicar√° un tiempo para poder ejercitar lo visto, previo a continuar con el siguiente contenido.
Se recomienda seguir las presentaciones durante la exposici√≥n ya que de ellas se extraer√° el c√≥digo, haciendo m√°s √°gil la cursada.

title: Puesta a punto
text:
Estrategias metodol√≥gicas y Recursos did√°cticos
Las clases del curso ser√°n te√≥rico-pr√°cticas. Por cada presentaci√≥n tem√°tica se ir√°n planteando ejercicios a medida que se avanza en el contenido, abordando las dudas que vayan surgiendo. Se prioriza la utilizaci√≥n del programa durante la clase.
A lo largo del curso se brindar√°n sintaxis al estilo ‚Äúnotas de clase‚Äù, en las cuales se plasman conjuntamente las l√≠neas de c√≥digo que se exponen y su correspondiente explicaci√≥n respecto a los procedimientos realizados. Finalmente, se propondr√°n ejercicios para resolver fuera de la clase con el objetivo de reforzar los conocimientos vistos en las mismas.
Se busca que, siempre que se pueda, el contenido, ejemplos y ejercicios representen problem√°ticas y desaf√≠os propios del campo en el que se encuentran insertos los y las participantes.

title: Puesta a punto
text:
Instalaci√≥n de R
Asegurate de tener instalado R en tu computadora previo a comenzar el taller. Desde R-project vas a poder hacerte de R.
Sugerencia: Para usuarios y usuarias con Windows en sus computadoras, instalar rtools, herramienta para poder trabajar con el paquete tidyverse.
De todas formas, una semana previo al comienzo del curso se enviar√° un tutorial con todo lo necesario para un arranque sin problemas.

title: Puesta a punto
text:
Instalaci√≥n de Rstudio
Rstudio es la plataforma desde donde se trabajar√° durante todo el taller. Si bien debemos tener instalado R, el programa que se abrir√° en cada clase y desde donde haremos los ejercicios es Rstudio.
Descargar Rstudio

title: Puesta a punto
text:
Descarga de Slack (versi√≥n escritorio)
La forma de comunicaci√≥n ser√° principalmente Slack, una plataforma de intercambio que funciona como un chat-foro. Desde all√≠ es posible concentrar la comunicaci√≥n del curso, difundir material, c√≥digo y tambi√©n realizar consultas y respuestas de forma grupal.

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text:
Outline

Why use Quarto to make teaching materials?
What teaching materials can I create using Quarto?
How do I get started?

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text:
Benefits for instructor

Reproducible course materials that are easier to update
Integrate narrative, executable R code, images, and interactive elements
Easily share course materials with students and more broadly
Regularly use the same technology as your students

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text:
Benefits for students

Navigation menu on all documents to easily to find content
Search capabilities on website to more easily find content by topic
Option to export PDF of slides
Read course materials on multiple devices

Interactive documents with webR

‚ÄúRun R code in the browser without the need for an R server to execute the code‚Äù




webR demo: maria.quarto.pub/webr-demo

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text:
webR source code
YAML

---
title: "webR document"
format: html
filters:
  - webr
webr:
  packages: ['dplyr', 'ggplot2']
  Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy: same-origin
  Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy: require-corp
---


Executable code chunk

{webr-r}
mpg |>
  count(manufacturer, _____)

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text:
Getting started: slides + documents


Basic
Customized




---
title: "Lecture 01"
subtitle: "Statistics 101"
author: "Instructor"
date: "August 7, 2023"
format: revealjs
---







Tip


Easily produce multiple types of documents by changing the format in the YAML.






---
title: "Lecture 01"
subtitle: "Statistics 101"
author: "Instructor"
date: "August 7, 2023"
date-format: long
footer: "URL to course website"
format: 
  revealjs:
    theme: slides.scss
    transition: fade
    slide-number: false
    incremental: false 
    chalkboard: 
    code-link: true
editor: visual
execute: 
  eval: true
  echo: true
---

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text:
Getting started: websites

Make a website repo on GitHub
Clone the repo and start a new RStudio project

Run the following code in the Terminal
quarto create-project --type website


You will see the standard files for a new website in the Files pane. See Creating a Website on quarto.org for more information.

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text:
Publishing materials
Run the following code in the Terminal
GitHub pages
quarto publish gh-pages
Quarto pub
quarto publish quarto-pub
Netlify
quarto publish netlify

See Publishing Basics on quarto.org for more information and publishing options.

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Engine Setup
In R Markdown, to use python, you had to set everything up in R using the reticulate package:

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text: library(reticulate)

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
library(reticulate)
py_config()
use_python("/usr/local/bin/python3")
py_discover_config()

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
library(reticulate)
py_config()
use_python("/usr/local/bin/python3")
py_discover_config()

## You may need the code below if you are working on your home Windows computer:
py_run_string("import os as os")
py_run_string("os.environ['QT_QPA_PLATFORM_PLUGIN_PATH'] = 'C:/Users/kbodwin/Anaconda3/Library/plugins/platforms'")

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
library(reticulate)
py_config()
use_python("/usr/local/bin/python3")
py_discover_config()

## You may need the code below if you are working on your home Windows computer:
py_run_string("import os as os")
py_run_string("os.environ['QT_QPA_PLATFORM_PLUGIN_PATH'] = 'C:/Users/kbodwin/Anaconda3/Library/plugins/platforms'")

reticulate::py_install("pandas")
reticulate::py_install("scikit-learn")
reticulate::py_install("scipy")

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Engine Setup
Now, it‚Äôs all ‚Äúunder the hood‚Äù:
---
title: "My document"
jupyter: python3
---

section: Choose your install in Global Options
text: Choose your install in Global Options

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Object passing

Automatic variables named py and r
Access python objects from R with py$
Access R objects from python with r.

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Object passing

```{r}
# read and filter data with R
library(palmerpenguins)

adelie <-
  penguins %>%
  filter(species == "Adelie")
```

```{python}
# model with python
LR = LinearRegression()

X = r.adelie[['bill_length_mm', 'bill_depth_mm']]
y = r.adelie['mass_g']

mod = LR.fit(X, y)
coef = mod.coef_
```

```{r}
# summarize with R
py$coef
```

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Jupyter

Do you like Jupyter notebooks? Me too!
Do you like Colab and/or Posit Cloud? Me too!
Do you want to make your materials in Quarto but distribute to students in Jupyter form? Me too!



Code
quarto convert class_notes.qmd
quarto convert class_notes.ipynb 

quarto render class_notes.ipynb

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Remaining challenges of multilingual docs

Most undergrad programs don‚Äôt require multiple languages.
Detecting python installs and packages isn‚Äôt perfect.
R and python do not always have the same default implementations for models.
What if what you want is not a multilingual document, but duplicated translated documents?

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
What it does
Upon rendering‚Ä¶

Identifies the R chunks from the python chunks
Identifies the labeled text sections for R or python.
Writes new unilingual source files (qmds) in separate folders
(Optionally) Renders those source files
(Optionally) Converts the python one to ipynb.

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
First chunk
```{r, version = "none"}
templar::versions_quarto_multilingual(global_eval = FALSE,
                                      to_jupyter = TRUE, 
                                      warn_edit = FALSE)
```

{version = "none"}: this code itself should not appear in generated files
global_eval: do you want to
to_jupyter: do you want to convert the python version?
warn_edit: put a warning at the top of generated files to not edit directly?

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Code chunk versions

The first thing we need to do with any dataset is check for
missing data, and make sure the variables are the right type:

```{r, version = "R"}
df %>% summary()
```

```{python, version = "python"}
df.info()
```

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Versioned text

The next step is to clean the data.

%%% version: R

The "Color" variable is being treated as a "character" variable,
i.e., just an ordinary word.

But we know it should be *categorical*, aka a `factor` variable.
Let's `mutate` the dataset to fix this:

```{r, version = "R"}
df <- df %>%
  mutate(
    Color = factor(Color)
  )

df %>% summary()
```

%%%

%%% version: python

The "Color" variable is being treated as an "object" variable,
i.e., just an ordinary word.

But we know it should be *categorical*, aka a `category` variable.
Let's *retype* the variable to fix this:

%%%

```{python, version = "python"}
kelly_df['Gender'] = kelly_df['Gender'].astype('category')
kelly_df.info()
```

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Why it‚Äôs useful

Keep the content creation all in one place - more reproducible!
Elements of the document can be shared - e.g.¬†data descriptions, question prompts, css chunks
Give you source files to disseminate to students, not just rendered files.
(Also lets you do student and solution version, or Exam A and Exam B, etc.)

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Lua translation

Parse the source file text more elegantly
Match syntax to Quarto‚Äôs
(::: instead of %%%)
(#| version: R instad of {version = "R})
Do you know Lua and knitr? Let‚Äôs be friends.

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Quarto‚Äôs multi-output trick
What it can do now:
---
title: "My Versioned Doc"
format: 
  html:
    output-file: my_versioned_doc.html
  pdf:
    output-file: my_versioned_doc.pdf
---

::: {.content-visible when-format="html"}
Click here to expand!
:::

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Quarto‚Äôs multi-output trick
What I want:
---
title: "My Versioned Doc"
format: 
  html+R:
    output-file: handout-r.html
  html+python:
    output-file: handout-python.html
---

::: {.content-visible when-variant="R"}
The function `mutate()` will add a new variable.
:::

title: Bilingual Materials with Quarto
text:
Resources
Install the templar package:

remotes::install_github("r-for-educators/templar")

Co-author: Ian Flores Siaca
Contribute at www.github.com/r-for-educators/templar
Examples of course materials generated with templar:
https://github.com/Statistical-Learning-with-R

title: Teaching Quarto in Introduction to Data Science Courses
text: Quarto, the next-generation version of R Markdown, is a powerful tool that helps students be more of an active participant in class while simultaneously highlighting the importance of reproducibility in science. In this talk, we discuss how to facilitate the use of Quarto into classroom pedagogy for students who are learning the programming language R and Quarto at the same time. In combination with R, this tool can help instructions create interactive live-coding experiences for students. Features of Quarto provide multiple ways for students to write code and type written answers to questions on their own, in groups, or along with the instructor during lecture. Students can also learn to create their own project reports, and turn their projects into hosted websites. In this session, we share how Quarto is used in an Introductory Data Science course for students with little to no coding experience at Duke University. Further, we go into benefits and challenges of teaching with Quarto from both the instructor and student perspective.

title: Teaching Quarto in Introduction to Data Science Courses
text: Quarto, the next-generation version of R Markdown, is a powerful tool that helps students be more of an active participant in class while simultaneously highlighting the importance of reproducibility in science. In this talk, we discuss how to facilitate the use of Quarto into classroom pedagogy for students who are learning the programming language R and Quarto at the same time. In combination with R, this tool can help instructions create interactive live-coding experiences for students. Features of Quarto provide multiple ways for students to write code and type written answers to questions on their own, in groups, or along with the instructor during lecture. Students can also learn to create their own project reports, and turn their projects into hosted websites. In this session, we share how Quarto is used in an Introductory Data Science course for students with little to no coding experience at Duke University. Further, we go into benefits and challenges of teaching with Quarto from both the instructor and student perspective.

title: Teaching Quarto in Introduction to Data Science Courses
text: Slides

title: Teaching Quarto in Introduction to Data Science Courses
text:
Speaker

Elijah Meyer (elijah.meyer@duke.edu) is currently a teaching postdoctoral associate at Duke University. Taught Quarto in introductory data science at Duke the last fall, spring, and summer sessions. His work focuses on curricula and course creation, as well as studying how to best support newer instructor‚Äôs use of active learning.

title: Encuentro 1 - Introducci√≥n a R y conceptos b√°sicos del lenguaje
text:
En este encuentro vamos a presentar a R, su contexto y su potencia, asi como tambi√©n introducirnos en sus conceptos b√°sicos, como lo son los valores, vectores, data frames y funciones.
Tendremos ejercitaci√≥n para realizar durante el encuentro y se dejar√° pr√°ctica para poder continuar incorporando el lenguaje durante la semana. La entrega de la pr√°ctica no es obligatoria, y las resoluciones se dar√°n al comienzo del encuentro siguiente.

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
R ‚Ä¶

Es un lenguaje de programaci√≥n especializado en an√°lisis y visualizaci√≥n de datos.

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
R ‚Ä¶

Es de c√≥digo abierto (se puede usar y modificar sin pagar licencias ni costos de ning√∫n tipo)

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
R ‚Ä¶

Crece a partir del aporte de su comunidad (no depende de un departamento de desarrollo):

Academia (Universidades)
Investigaci√≥n Cient√≠fica (Centros de investigaci√≥n, comunidad cient√≠fica)
Sector privado (Facebook, Google, X, Uber, Airbnb, IBM, New York times)
Gente de a pie (personas o grupos de personas)

R ‚Ä¶

En el campo del an√°lisis de datos, es la herramienta por excelencia en muchas universidades, empresas de tecnolog√≠a, y redacciones de periodismo de datos.

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Funciones

Las funciones en R son el alma mater del lenguaje (de todos los lenguajes)
ellas reciben un input y devuelven un output
Siempre las encontrar√°s escrita as√≠:

nombre_de_la_funcion(input)

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Funciones

La funci√≥n class() devuelve el tipo del valor o vector que le de (input)


class(1)

[1] "numeric"

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Funciones

La funci√≥n length() devuelve el largo del input (probemos con un vector):


length(c(10, 20, 30))

[1] 3

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Funciones

La funci√≥n mean() calcula el promedio de un input (tiene que ser si o si num√©rico):


mean(c(10, 20, 30))

[1] 20

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Funciones

mean(c("10", "20", "30"))

[1] NA

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Objectos

Todo en R puede ser guardado en un objeto (un valor, un vector, el resutlado de una funci√≥n, y m√°s)

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Objectos

Todo en R puede ser guardado en un objeto (un valor, un vector, el resutlado de una funci√≥n, y m√°s)
Para guardar algo en un objeto, tengo que seguir la siguiente estructura:

nombre_del_objeto <- algo

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Objectos

guardo_un_numero <- 1

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Objectos

guardo_un_numero

[1] 1

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Objectos

guardo_un_vector <- c(10, 20, 30)

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Objectos

guardo_un_vector

[1] 10 20 30

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Objectos

guardo_un_resultado <- mean(c(20, 45, 23))

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Objectos

guardo_un_resultado

[1] 29.33333

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Objectos

objeto_como_input <- c(20, 45, 23)

mean(objeto_como_input)

[1] 29.33333

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Ejercitaci√≥n

Crear un objeto con los siguientes 5 valores num√©ricos: 17, 92, 56, 32 y 102, y llamarlo edad_personas.
Con la funci√≥n class() chequear de qu√© tipo es el objeto.
Con la funci√≥n length() conocer la longitud de ese objeto (cu√°ntos valores tiene).
Calcular el promedio de esos valores (la edad promedio)

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Data Frames

Un Data Frame (o tabla) es la combinaci√≥n de vectores (variables), que termina conformando una relaci√≥n entre filas y columnas.
Cada vector es una columna de un dataframe, y cada uno de sus valores, en el orden en que se encuentran, conforman las filas.

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Data Frames

Para crear un Data Frame puedo utilizar la funci√≥n data.frame(), cuyos inputs son los vectores:


vector_edad <- c(20, 43, 102, 56)
vector_nombre <- c("Pepe", "Pepa", "Rigoberto", "Rodoberta")

base_personas <- data.frame(vector_edad,
                            vector_nombre)

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Data Franes

As√≠ se ve un data.frame:


base_personas

  vector_edad vector_nombre
1          20          Pepe
2          43          Pepa
3         102     Rigoberto
4          56     Rodoberta

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Accediendo a un Data Frames

Con el comando $ (s√≠mbolo peso) puedo acceder a una columna del data frame:

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Accediendo a un Data Frane

base_personas$vector_nombre

[1] "Pepe"      "Pepa"      "Rigoberto" "Rodoberta"

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Accediendo a un Data Frane
El resultado de base_personas$vector_nombre es nuevamente un vector, por lo que puedo:

class(base_personas$vector_nombre)

[1] "character"



length(base_personas$vector_nombre)

[1] 4

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
Ejercitaci√≥n

Crear un vector llamado serie, cuyos valores son: "Berl√≠n", "The Crown" y "Vikings".
Crear un vector llamado puntaje, cuyos valores son (agregar puntaje a gusto),
Crear un data.frame llamado netflix, que combine los vectores anteriores
Calcular el puntaje promedio de las series de Netflix.

title: Introducci√≥n a R base
text:
¬°Listo!

Nos vemos el encuentro que viene.
Seguimos la comunicaci√≥n entre clase y clase por Slack
Ac√° dejamos m√°s ejercitaci√≥n para seguir practicando

title: Quarto and automation in teaching statistical computing
text: In this talk we will discuss the use of GitHub actions and Quarto to provide automated feedback to students in a variety of statistical computing courses. These courses span the undergraduate and graduate curriculum and make use of both R and Python. The flexibility and power of the Quarto framework provide for the development of common tooling and workflows that can be adapted the specific needs of each course. We will provide concrete examples of how these tools are currently being used in these courses as well as discussing how they can be extended and adopted for new courses.

title: Quarto and automation in teaching statistical computing
text: In this talk we will discuss the use of GitHub actions and Quarto to provide automated feedback to students in a variety of statistical computing courses. These courses span the undergraduate and graduate curriculum and make use of both R and Python. The flexibility and power of the Quarto framework provide for the development of common tooling and workflows that can be adapted the specific needs of each course. We will provide concrete examples of how these tools are currently being used in these courses as well as discussing how they can be extended and adopted for new courses.

Colin Rundel is Associate Professor of the Practice at Duke University where he has been teaching since 2012. His work focuses on teaching statistical computing to both undergraduate and graduate students in both R and Python.

title: Blending R and Python in Quarto documents
text: Data science teams are increasingly ‚Äúmultilingual‚Äù, using more than one statistical computing tool for analyses and models. While many typesetting and notebook approaches support more than one language, Quarto is specifically designed for this flexibility. In particular, Quarto offers the ability to combine source code in both R and python into one single, reproducible document. These new capabilities have made it easier than ever to incorporate both languages simultaneously into statistics and data science courses. In this talk, I will give an overview of the advantages and drawbacks of using Quarto for ‚Äúbilingual‚Äù materials in the data science classroom. I‚Äôll also offer some tips and tricks - as well as some helper scripts - for managing these blended documents.

title: Blending R and Python in Quarto documents
text: Data science teams are increasingly ‚Äúmultilingual‚Äù, using more than one statistical computing tool for analyses and models. While many typesetting and notebook approaches support more than one language, Quarto is specifically designed for this flexibility. In particular, Quarto offers the ability to combine source code in both R and python into one single, reproducible document. These new capabilities have made it easier than ever to incorporate both languages simultaneously into statistics and data science courses. In this talk, I will give an overview of the advantages and drawbacks of using Quarto for ‚Äúbilingual‚Äù materials in the data science classroom. I‚Äôll also offer some tips and tricks - as well as some helper scripts - for managing these blended documents.

title: Blending R and Python in Quarto documents
text:
Speaker





Kelly Bodwin is an Associate Professor of Statistics and Data Science at Cal Poly, in San Luis Obispo, CA. Her research includes R package development, studies of statistical education, and applications in a variety of fields such as history, biology, and viticulture. While R will always be her first love, she is slowly learning to accept python into her life.

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text: In addition to creating reproducible documents, Quarto offers a rich suite of options for creation slide decks, books, and websites, allowing instructors to create all of their teaching materials reproducibly. In this talk we will demo how we‚Äôve been using Quarto to create and organize teaching materials, introduce resources and templates for getting started with Quarto for organizing your own teaching materials, and share best practices.

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text: In addition to creating reproducible documents, Quarto offers a rich suite of options for creation slide decks, books, and websites, allowing instructors to create all of their teaching materials reproducibly. In this talk we will demo how we‚Äôve been using Quarto to create and organize teaching materials, introduce resources and templates for getting started with Quarto for organizing your own teaching materials, and share best practices.

title: Using Quarto for Making and Organizing Teaching Materials
text:
Speaker





Maria Tackett is an Assistant Professor of the Practice in the Department of Statistical Science at Duke University. Her research focuses on understanding factors that impact students‚Äô sense of belonging in introductory math and statistics courses with the aim to identify pedagogies that foster community and a supportive learning environment. She‚Äôs an active member of the statistics education community and its effort to make statistics more engaging and accessible for all students.

title: Docente
text:
PABLO TISCORNIA
Soci√≥logo y Cient√≠fico de Datos. Especializado en metodolog√≠a, producci√≥n, procesamiento y comunicaci√≥n de informaci√≥n estad√≠stica. Trabaj√© como analista y procesador de datos en las oficinas estad√≠sticas de la Ciudad de Buenos Aires (DGEyC) y Argentina (INDEC), y como Coordinador de Datos en la Direcci√≥n Nacional de Mercados y Estad√≠stica (DNMYE), del Ministerio de Turismo y Deportes de la Naci√≥n. Actualmente estoy trabajando como Cient√≠fico de datos para C40 Cities.
